U.S. Troops' Presence in S. Korea Denounced 
    Pyongyang, September 16 (KCNA) -- Heinrich Gruber, chairman of the Vienna, 21 County Branch of the Communist Party of Austria, denounced the U.S. troops' presence in south Korea.
 He issued a statement on Sept. 5 58 years after the U.S. forces' occupation of south Korea. The statement noted that their presence in south Korea is a symbol of the division of Korea and a main obstacle to its independent and peaceful reunification.    
 Demanding an immediate withdrawal from south Korea of the U.S. troops, a main hurdle lying in the way of the reunification and peace of the Korean peninsula, he expressed solidarity with the Korean people in their efforts for the independent and peaceful reunification of the country.

S. Korean Visiting Group Arrives
    Pyongyang, September 16 (KCNA) -- A visiting group of south Korean NGO "Let-Koreans-Help-Each-Other Movement" led by its permanent representative Song Hyon Sop arrived in Pyongyang today.
 It was met at the airport with compatriotic feelings by Ho Hyok Phil, vice-chairman of the National Reconciliation Council, and other officials concerned.

articles.title: Choe Thae Bok Meets British Guests
articles.content:
IIJI Congratulatory Group Leaves
    Pyongyang, September 16 (KCNA) -- A congratulatory group of the International Institute of the Juche Idea led by Secretary General Vishwanath left Pyongyang today.
 It was seen off at the airport by Kim Yong Il, vice-chairman of the Korean Social Scientists Society.

Choe Thae Bok Meets British Guests
    Pyongyang, September 16 (KCNA) -- Choe Thae Bok, chairman of the Supreme People's Assembly of the DPRK, met and had a friendly talk with Caroline Anne Cox, vice-president of the House of Lords of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and her party who paid a courtesy call on him at the Mansudae Assembly Hall today.
 Present there were Deputy to the SPA Ri Jong Hyok, chairman of the DPRK-Britain Friendship Parliamentary Group, and officials concerned.
